title: Ticket #3718: Detect invalid interpreter in script
description:
It's not-so-uncommon for a user to specify a bad interpreter in a shell script they submit to condor: 

#!/bin/bsh

When this happens, the user gets the following hold message: 

Error from slot3@hcc-briantest.unl.edu: Failed to execute '/tmp/foo': (errno=2: 'No such file or directory')

This is incredibly misleading - anyone who hasn't memorized every HTCondor failure mode will immediately think /tmp/foo doesn't exist and look for filesystem issues. That's certainly what I do!

I propose to adopt the error handling logic for this case from /bin/bash and properly detect the bad interpreter. Here's my proposed hold message: 

[bbockelm@hcc-briantest condor]$ condor_q -held


-- Submitter: hcc-briantest.unl.edu : <129.93.244.208:44063> : hcc-briantest.unl.edu
 ID       OWNER          HELD_SINCE  HOLD_REASON
23319.0   bbockelm        6/24 21:51 Error from slot3@hcc-briantest.unl.edu: Failed to execute '/tmp/foo': invalid interpreter (/bin/blah) specified on first line of script (errno=2: 'No such file or directory')

1 jobs; 0 completed, 0 removed, 0 idle, 0 running, 1 held, 0 suspended

Patch on the V8_1-bad-interpreter branch.
remarks:
2013-Jun-24 22:01:35 by bbockelm:
gthain, ready for review.

2013-Jun-25 10:19:42 by gthain:
CODE REVIEW

Can we close script_fd? I know we're on our way out at this point, but not closing it will annoy our static analyzers.

What happens in the case where there's a space between #! and the interpreter? IIRC, is that a distinct error?

Should we put the job on hold in this case or not? Is it more likely for someone to misspell /usr/bin/perl, or to land on one machine in the pool that doesn't have perl?

2013-Jun-25 13:04:36 by bbockelm:
  • Having the space in "#! /bin/bash" appears to be acceptable. Job runs fine.
  • I'll fix the script_fd.
  • I think putting things on hold is the most appropriate way forward - it mimics what happens with other exec errors. It's just an improvement in the error message, not a change in semantics.

If you're OK with it, I propose fixing the fd leak and pushing.

2013-Jun-25 15:14:13 by gthain:
AFter talking this over with todd, he'd really profer that this just go into the starter.

2013-Jun-25 16:47:56 by bbockelm:
What's the thinking behind that?

As we're just improving the error message, should benefit all DaemonCore users.

2015-Apr-09 19:50:29 by bbockelm:
Talked to ToddT; he disclaims any knowledge of the preference of putting it into the Starter itself. Yay for old age!

I'm going to fix script_fd, run it through NMI, and merge on up.
